OCTOBER 1, 1953
BETTER BROADCASTS NEWS LETTER
THREE
What You Can Do
About Television
condensed from an article in the Junior
League Magazine, by Nancy Falkner,
now radio-TV columnist for
Scholastic Teacher
Usually it will be more practical to in¬
fluence local television offerings for chil¬
dren without rushing to produce your own
series. Here are some things you, with the
help of other civic groups, can do effectively:
1. Know the local station’s programs.
2. Decide what kind of shows you want,
and why.
3. Interest other community groups to
work with you.
4. Tell your local station what you
want.
5. Be constructive and practical.
It’s no good calling all current shows of a
kind “terrible”. They aren’t. Shows like
“Mr. Wizard” (science), “Through the En¬
chanted Gate” (arts), Mr. I. Magination
(story-telling), ‘lelaventure Tales.” (books)
“Zoo Parade” — all are top entertainment
and good value for the viewers. Take the
time to follow your local station for at least
a month and log the good, bad, and indif¬
ferent.
Do your viewing (of children’s programs)
with your children as often as possible. Lis¬
ten to their opinions of the shows. Find out
through your local papers or the TV trade
papers such as “Variety” and fan magazines
such as “TV Guide” what other shows exist
for children.
TAKE THE LEAD. Enlist the aid of
Scouts, Camp-Fire Girls, schools, churches,
PTA’s, women’s clubs, and other groups.
Take the lead in organizing these groups to
look and evaluate and form a program of
improvement with you. One voice—even
the voice of one organization—is a lost
voice. When all interested community groups
combine to plead the same case, action will
result.
When you approach your local station,
it should not be just to throw rocks. The
impersonal “station” will turn into a person
—a man who is more easily caught with
honey than with vinegar. So hand out orch¬
ids for the programs you believe are ex¬
cellent. Then suggest that all the community
groups whom you are representing can and
will put their full weight behind more such
programs.
Be ywarned .by radio. Before the public
finally rose against the worst aspects of
children’s radio programs, the program pat¬
tern was already set. In the face of apparent
success with objectionable programs, the
combined efforts of all the dissatisfied par¬
ents, teachers, ministers, and civic groups
couldn’t cancel the evils of over-exciting
serials. They could only now and then
supplement the bad with better programs,
which often failed to appeal to children
jaded by strong fare.
Station managers are always sensitive to
the voice of the public. Their operation in¬
come depends on the number of sets tuned to
their call letters. So your proposals must
be backed by strong, organized community
pressure. You are dealing with individuals
who are your own good neighbors, with the
same concern for the community that you
have. If you can show them they won’t lose
audience and money on the kind of programs
you want, you’re in.
NOTE: What is said here about children’s
programs is true of all programs, and of
radio as well as television.
Tea, Preparations, Institute
TEA
Representatives of many organizations
drank tea with Mrs. W. A. Lucht, President
of the Illinois Council on Motion Pictures,
Radio, Television, and Publications, and
planned the Fall Workshop. Mrs. Mead
Messick, chairman of Radio-TV Committee,
will conduct the workshop on the Look-
Listen Project. Last year, under her chair¬
manship in AAUW, 750 members of the
Illinois AAUW participated in the Project.
PROJECT PREPARATIONS
The California State Division of AAUW
has already ordered material for the Look-
Listen Project, and is ready to distribute
it this month. For three years it has been
a valuable part of the Look-Listen Project,
and for many years has been working for
better radio-TV programs.
INSTITUTE, OCT. 22, MADISON
You are invited to the Wisconsin Better
Radio-TV Institute in Great Hall of the
University Union, Oct. 22. It will consider
the Evaluation of Radio-TV Drama, Mak¬
ing Your Opinions Felt, and Educational
Television. Dean Kenneth Bartlett of Syra¬
cuse University will be the main speaker.
The Institute aims to help youth and
adults to work together for better programs.
Last year one third of the audience were
high school students.
News Items
The American Research Bureau now
records not only the number of sets tuned
to a certain television program, but also the
number of people watching it. According
to ARB findings, about the same number of
sets were tuned to “Mr. Peepers” and “Mar¬
tin Kane.” But “Mr. Peepers” had four
and a half million more viewers.
“Omnibus” is reported to be putting on
a ninety minute version of “King Lear” this
fall, with Petter Brook, one of England’s
top Shakespearean directors, staging it.
“World-Wide Playhouse” will show
United Nations activity in dramatic form.
The aggregate income of radio stations in
areas served by television increased 2% in
1952 over 1951, according to FCC figures.
Italian movie stars, such as Anna Magnani
and Vittorio Gassman, will be seen on
American television this winter, with Eng¬
lish dubbings.
Britain has decided to accept advertising
on its TV programs, but not sponsors. In
other words the BBC will still be responsible
for the programming. The British make this
comparison: “The press accepts ads, but
they remain responsible for their own news
and editorial columns.”
Maurice Evans is planning a two-hour
version of Macbeth, probably to be soon on
the Hallmark Hall of Fame.

An Introduction to ACBB Officers
The Seven Criteria of Franklin Dunham,
Chief of Radio-TV, U. S. Office of Edu¬

Many other short articles.
Listen, This Month, to:
New York Philharmonic Sun., 2:30 p.m.
CBS.
NBC Symphony, Sat., 6:30, NBC
Chicago Symphony, Wed., 8:30 MBS.
Would it be a good idea for members of
the Council to ask members of their organ¬
izations to notice how many times in the
coming month they listen to these programs,
and hand in their score at the next meet¬
ing? “Newsletter” would be interested in
your reaction to this question; also to your
score sheet, if you make one.
Will Stress Mass
Communications
Scholastic Teacher, 33 W. 42nd St., New
York 36, N.Y., is running a column, “We
Tried This.” The editor, W. D. Boutwell,
would like to have short reports on how
Junior and Senior High School teachers in
class discussion helped students evaluate
out-of-school radio-TV programs. He is
especially interested in evidence of pro¬
jects along the line of comparative analysis
of news commentators. If you know of such
projects, will you write to him.
In the same magazine Nancy Faulkner
edits a column on radio and television. The
September and November issues will carry
news of this Council.
Buy the Advertising that
Pleases You
When you buy, you are influenced chief¬
ly by the quality of the article, and by how
much you get for your money. In these,
respects competing products are often ap¬
proximately the same. When they are, do
you buy products advertised in ways you
like—that is, by excellent programs with
acceptable advertising? You buy a certain
type of advertising when you buy. Do you
encourage the kind of commercial that in¬
cites Junior to tease Mom to rush to the
store and buy XYZ? Let your dollar follow
your taste.
One thing more—TELL the merchant that
you have bought the product because of
the quality, plus the good program, plus
the good advertising.
One Joins
ONE JOINS ACBB for two reasons:
1. he knows that those who want pro¬
grams of quality need to unite on a national
basis.
2. he believes citizens should make a
little effort to STUDY the quality of pro¬
grams and EXPRESS their opinions ef¬
fectively and with force of numbers.
